reviewText: I found this performance bizarre; the whole production seemed strange.  It was not an avant-garde one, but done with a pretense for historical accuracy.  Yet the costumes of the chorus suggested something totally different from 17century Moscow. Were they Polish or Ukrainian?  Someone did not seem to do their homework.I actually liked Marusin as Prince Golitzyn.  I think he had squillo and also he acted quite well.  Paata Burchuladze seems to always play the same role, no matter whether he is in this opera or in Don Giovanni.  The singing is good, though.  I must admit that only main roles that are either Russians or Bulgarian Ghiaurov, sing intelligibly, although Ghiaurov happenned to have a heavier accent that I would have thought.  But for me as a native Russian speaker, the singing of the chorus and other's smaller roles were a real disappointment as I could not understand a word and had to resort to subtitles and it was a real distraction. I wonder if Italians have the same feeling when they listen to their opera performed by foreign singers...In any case, it's a satisfactory performance but I think the complexity of the work was not resolved here, and the beauty of this opera was not fully conveyed.  It looked rather Wagnerian to me but it is not and I believe it had to be done with more respect to its Russion origin, or be totally devoid of place and time to become an avant-garde production.

reviewText: I've had this recording for some years. I've listened to it often trying to resolve matters of the production and musical interpretation. Some things I liked immediately and still do, others I have misgivings about and a few are downright negative. This has all come to a head now because of the release of a 1979 recording from the Bolshoi of a truly Russian rendering (Bolshoi, Yuri Simonov conducting 1979 Rimsky-Korsakov edition). The 1989 Vienna State is masterfully led by Claudio Abbado. He has a repectful feel for the music of Mussorgsky and the Vienna is a great musical ensemble. The featured singers are also masterful in their individual  numbers and are often great. Paata Burchuladze as Dosifie has a shimmering, soul-lifting bass in contrast to the faded glory of N. Ghiaurov as Prince Khovansky. (This may actually fit the faded glory of the aged war hero prince). I remember in the 1960s the glorous voiced Nicolai in Boris, Don Carlo and numerous other star bass roles. The Boyar Shaklovity has one of the opera's best arias - about hope for relief from oppression in these troubled times for Russia, This was breathtakingly conveyed by Anatoly Kocherga. The solo numbers were all given well.It was the music in between the vocal numbers that was disturbing. This production used the 1959 re-orchestration of Shostakovich. No matter how many times I hear this I envision/remember one of the war symphonies or Lady Macbeth of Misensk and it's livid 20th century music and not the rough, crude, earthy music of the downtrodden serfs of oppresed 17th century Russia. This holds as well for the last chorus of the "Old Believers" in the finale. It is a truly beautiful piece but not appropriate here. Stravinsky wrote much service music for the Russian Orthodox church and was a devout believer. He had a natural sympathy for this radical religious group and makes them out to be martyrs. However in history they were much more malignant and opposed to any change or modernization. So in the Rimsky-Korsakov version it's their  obstinacy that is the cause of their immolation. Religions are forever splitting off because some new "revelation" comes to some individual or group; as many as all the grains of sand on all the oceans' beaches are the gods invented by the human mind. (Dosifei is an invention for the opera as the "Old Believers" sect had no leaders; Marfa was also an invention but all the other major roles are historical figures).There is little complete music extant that was fully written by Mussorgsky for Khovanshchina but I feel that the Rinsky version is closer to the unbiased history as envisioned by Mussorogsky (was there any use in all that happened or was it all so many ashes in the dust-bin of History?) Yes, Rimsky took some liberties and you can hear a little Sadko here and there but it's sounds more appropriate to me than 20th century Shostakovich.A last comment about production and singing Russian: listen to the chorus in the Bolshoi-Simonov recording. Russian music sung by Russians can be magical and moving. And there is magic in that production too. You feel transported back in time and can feel the pain of the downtrodden peasants and the oppression of their country. The Vienna-Abbado-Kirchner Star Wars-Buck Rogers spectacle was scary at times but otherwise pointless

reviewText: While this quirky staging is not ideal, this is overall the best Khovanshchina generally available on DVD.  It is uncut and features the beautiful conclusion to Act V composed by no less than Igor Stravinsky, far more atmosphere than the relatively banal upbeat conclusion that Shostakovich was compelled by the dictates of "Socialist  Realism" to compose for his otherwise superb orchestration of Mussorgsky's incomplete score.  The singers are a potent lot, although by this time Burchuladze had seen better days vocally and  Ghiaurov was getting on in years as well.  Abbado is not the most idiomatic of stylists in Mussorgsky, but his dedication and phenomenal technical mastery pay dividends.  This is far superior to the threadbare (both visually and vocally) Bolshoi Opera performance on Kultur and the disappointingly wooden Gergiev/Kirov Opera performance.  Most other DVD versions are badly sung and feature bizarre modern stagings (though that from the Teatro Liceu in Barcelona under Michael Boder, set in Stalin's Russia c. 1950, is as riveting visually as it is badly sung vocally).  Do, however, try to lay your hands on the Dream Life DVD (issued only in Japan) of the 1959 film version starring the fabled Mark Reizen as Dosifei and conducted by Yevgeny Svetlanov.  It has standard theater cuts, and notes only in Japanese and Russian, but it's a terrific performance in a fascinating traditional setting.
summary: Not perfect, but the best genally available

reviewText: Tolstoy once said: "I like neither talented drunks nor drunken talents" thereby wittily dismissing Mussorgsky. Mussorgsky however cannot be pushed aside so easily ( even if Tolstoy was right; it took no less than three composers to finish the work,left in a sorry unfinished state.)Abbado, who is undisputably today's greatest interpreter ofMussorgsky, chose, very wisely, the Shostakovich orchestrationwho created a dark hued, sombre score that he handles masterfully.In fact we go from the aethereal strings (The Prelude) to thedark bases representing the brutal strenghth of the Khovanskysand the ensuing conflicts. Distant trumpets create magical effects. This DVD sound is superb( and if I may say so, you are far better off with this than the exorbiantly priced CD set)And to see it!  The design is incredible. Sets are surrealisticin a way, full of disturbing images suiting the mood of the moment. Screens sometimes close creating claustrophobic effects,sometimes opening to infinite vistas. Sometimes we see ruined cities or pyramid of skulls, the latters seems like a constant theme reminding us of the concluding tragedy.The principals...  Nicolai Ghiarov, the world famous basso, actsand sings with tremendous power, a multifaceted tragic character.Paata Burchuladze, another marvelous basso, shines as Dosifey thehigh priest. We must also mention Anatoly Kocherga in the role of Shaklovity the evil Boyar, thoroughlyfrightening, but believable - his great aria in third act isone to watch for. Ludmila Semtchuk as Marfa is beautifully actedand sung, she is a real feast for the eye as well as the ear.Last but not least, Heinz Zednik, the scribbler, ( of Bayreuth's Mime fame) herehe sings in Russian as if the role was created for him.Note of caution: The music is difficult and requires repeated listenings. Watch it one act at a time as the opera is very long.But I assure you, you will love this work as I came to love it, being a sceptic at first.Do I need to sum up? Great musical and theatrical experience.Opera at its best. Can't recommend it enough.
summary: Abbado brings great insight to Mussorgsky's masterpiece.

reviewText: If you love powerful music, political intrigue, epic historical drama, and rich characterization, do not miss Mussorgsky's Khovanshchina.  It is what Mussorgsky called a "nationalist people's musical drama," one fit for our age; it is only opera I know of that can give you insight into the tensions of our times:  the turmoil of Afghanistan and Iraq.  These are lands struggling with modernism, autocracy, religious fanaticism, feudal fiefdoms, and fears of the West.  All this was true of Russia when Peter the Great was coming of age and when Prince Ivan Khovansky, in league and in rivalries with false westernizers (like Prince Golitizan) and the Old Believers, sought to create their putsch against the imperial power of the Romanovs.The music is wonderful, providing melodic depth to every nuance of this psychosocial epic.  It is more subtle and mature "Boris Godunov," but no less moving.  Yet Khovanshchina does have its problems:  Peter the Great, the central figure of the drama, is absent.  Russian law forbade Mussorgsky from depicting members of the Romanov family on stage (so, too, the palace intrigues between Peter and his sister, Sophia, could not be shown).  So, dramatically it lacks the tightness of Boris.  Neither could Mussorgsky depict Patriarch Nikon, whose reforms so inflamed that Old Believers that, by the end of the opera, they immolate themselves.  Mussorgsky died with Khovanshchina barely sketched, so musicologists still debate his point of view (I think Kirchner and the Vienna State got it wrong, but no matter).The production is a fine one:  well conducted by Claudio Abbado, beautifully sung, and often brilliantly acted (most especially by Ghiaurov as Ivan Khovansky and Zednik as the scribe).  The dance of the Persian slaves is marvelously sensual, and the staging, while variable in quality is generally excellent - superb in Khovansky's rally and in the immolation scene.  Technically, it is very well recorded, though in standard frame and just in stereo.  Enjoy it now; don't just wait for a DTS version.  At 173 minutes on 1 DVD you're certainly getting your money's worth.
summary: A Fine Performance of a Most Extraordinary Work

reviewText: Khovanshchina is possibly the greatest opera that isn't one of the householdtitles (like Carmen and Boris Godunov). It's an extraordinary piece, filled withtwisty plot motion and bizarre characters, everyone at odds with everyone else,even with individuals who are on the same political side. The music favors slowtempos too much, perhaps, and the story can be hard to follow as some connecting plot tissueis simply not there, by the composer's determination. Boris is like that as well,but it has fewer characters and is thus easier to navigate through.Still, this is an enthralling piece, with plenty of opportunity for the singers toetch fascinating portraits and lots of challenges to the director in terms of crowdcontrol. I don't think this production succeeds very well in either case. The cast isvariable--no one's terrible, but some are just okay--and the staging and design aredisappointing, the former ordinary and the latter...well, let's just say inexpensive.The Met production really shows you what Moscow looks like; why doesn't Vienna do so,too?I think the most disappointing aspect is the musical one, because Abbado recordedthis production for DG with mostly the same cast, and that set is one of the bestopera recordings of its day. Somehow, the magic fails here. I don't think it's becauseNicolai Ghiaurov is past his prime as Ivan Khovansky (it's Auge Haugland on the CDs),because he nevertheless conveys all the roaring craziness of the character, who'svery much past his own prime. I can't say exactly why the discs are musically morefulfilled, but the DG box has the command here. Ideally, one might get the discs andsplurge for the Bolshoi DVD, an old-hat presentation, but with a formidable castin real-live pictorial sets.

reviewText: "Khovanshchina", while rating slightly behind "Boris Godunov" in Russian canon of great operas that also includes Eugene Onegin, The Queen of Spades, Sadko, and Prince Igor, presents the most fascinating insight into the times of the Peter the Great and also - of Mussorgsky himself.The composer, while the most troubled, was also an unparalleled genius, and his works were unmistakably Russian in melody and spirit and didn't borrow any ideas from his Western contemporaries, quite unlike his colleagues'.  "Khovanshchina" is a testimony to this aspect of his music probably more than anything else he has written.  The reckless abandon of Ivan Khovansky amidst the growing tension and his own impeding end, Marfa's paganism coupled with blind faith, and Shaklovity's sincere love for his sad motherland conflicting with his own conniving actions - these paradoxical examples make total sense the way Mussorgsky written them and the way any Russian (me being one) understands them.As of the opera's writing, a tsar (and actually, I believe, any member of the Romanov family), could not be portrayed on stage, so Peter the Great's presence is made felt through musical means.  He was a revered and terrifying figure at the same time.  In his quest to modernize Russia in a record time he didn't really take the feelings or the lives of his people into account.  A coup by "streltsy", which was really a type of military class, or musketeers, was threatening his throne itself.  They represented the old patriarchal and rather serf Russia, something Peter wanted to eradicate.  At the same time, the fanatical "starovery", or old-believers, were a direct threat to both the modern, more permissive Orthodox Church and to streltsy, whose drunken debauchery was not to their liking.  So here we have a conflict of three main powers: the tsar, the streltsy, and the old-believers.  In addition, a pretty weird love story between the old-believer Marfa, who also embodies some of the pagan strands that remained in the society, and Khovansky -fils, who really wants nothing to do with her anymore is vividly portrayed.  If all of that wasn't enough, we have a new noble class striving rather fruitlessly for power, represented by Prince Golitsyn, whose allegiance is to Peter's half-sister Sophia.  This makes for a very convoluted plot.  Thankfully, it's not transported into another time/place by director Alfred Kirchner.  However, it does feature a very dark final scene, composed by Igor Stravinsky in 1913.  Personally, I would rather be without it, as it adds little to the story and a lot more to the body-count.  But it has one valid point: the ending is the old-believers' mournful singing, as they self-immolate, not the trumpets of Peter's new western-style army, as Rimsky-Korsakov's version ended.  This changes the whole point of the opera: instead of welcoming the new era it mourns the lives and the fates of Russia's people. The orchestration is Shostakovich's, rather than familiar Rimsky-Korsakov's, but it really works here, emphasizing a surreal element already made prominent by the director.The voices are nothing short of magnificent.  Even though the great Bulgarian basso Nicolai Ghiaurov is a little past his glorious prime, he's still a force of nature.  He doesn't blaster too much here, but instead sings with great dignity and almost in Italianate style.  His Ivan Khovansky is a real ruler; one can see why Tsar Peter would want him dead.  His son, sang by Bolshoi tenor Vladimir Atlantov, is the opposite.  A spoiled libertine, he's but a distraction, and only comes to his senses - or succumbs to fatalism - at the very end.  The real surprise is Dosifey, sang by Georgian basso Paata Burchuladze.  He has an enormous voice and employs a lowered-larynx technique of the real-world Orthodox Church liturgical basses.  The results are astounding.  I heard Burchuladze in quite a few other operas, but none suite him better than this role. Anatoly Kotcherga is a Russian basso, a well-known Mussorgsky specialist.  He has done song cycles and even sang Dosifey.  In the role of boyar Shaklovity he sings a beautiful aria longing for peace and freedom for his troubled motherland.  And then, of course, proceeds to treacherously eradicate the main threat to this peace in his mind - the streltsy.  Note the clues from Kotcherga - he's making his character decidedly evil, not a good thing for Tsar Peter's agent. Prince Golitsyn, a nobleman in the newly adopted Western style, complete with a wig and a walking cane, is an unpleasant figure, but is sang beautifully and powerfully (after all, he has to go head-to-head with both Ghiaurov and Burchuladze) by Yuri Marussin.  And Ludmila Semtchuk is singing Marfa, the powerhouse of love and sacrifice, with gorgeous tone and total commitment.  Also worth mentioning is the wonderful Heinz Zednik who manages a very passable Russian as the Scribe.But all this wealth of talent would be a guarantee of success had it not been for maestro Claudio Abbado.  I just continue to marvel - is there anything this man can't conduct to perfection?  From Verdi to Mahler to Brahms to Tchaikovsky, Abbado's skills and ability to propel the action forward while giving ample support to the singers are probably unmatched today.A couple of "extra" or fine touches - you see that supposedly "lecherous" Ivan Khovansky is actually trying to lose himself in the dim and short-lived debauchery. By the by, Mussorsky's "Polovitsian Dances" are very different from Borodin's ("Prince Igor") - they're understated on purpose and neatly done.  Also, Dosifey sports a ring and no beard.  The girl that Andrei Khovansky is abducting in the beginning isn't really all that willing to be freed.  And the drunkards' wives appear sufficiently infuriated rather than sad.Overall, a spectacular achievement, one is left to wonder how this was even possible outside of Russia.My only regret is that it didn't make it to the CD with this cast.  Swapping two major characters - of Ivan Khovansky and Marfa - for fine, but different (and heavily accented) singers effectively did away with some of the magic.  Therefore, the Khovanschina to get on CD remains this one:Mussorgsky: Khovanshchina.Some 172 minutes of grandeur isn't easy to absorb, but I found myself coming back to it over and over.  I even replaced the VHS I had with this newer 2-DVD edition.  Highly recommended.
summary: Rare and wonderful opportunity to hear and see one of the grandest operas ever written

reviewText: This would be near-perfect if not for geriatric Ghiaurov who was once a great, intimidating Ivan Khovansky.  What a shame they didn't use Aage Haugland!  No one understands macho vulgarity the way he did.  Or, Matti Salminen, in 1989 he'd have blown the roof off the place.Everyone else is just tip-top, so much so that there's no point in listing them all.  Anatoly Kotcherga gives a real voice lesson for bass-baritones.  He has everything--big, dark, rich tone up to his very top, intimidating stage-presence, brains, and sincerity.  He and Paata Burchuladse are the ones to watch, especially if you're learning the "low-larynx" singing technique.  I used to think Burchuladse was affecting his exaggeratedly deep vowels and Hotter-esque wobble but watching him I see it's just his natural vocal shape and size, which are extreme.  Extremely extreme.Heinz Zednik is fantastic as the Scribe--but as I said, the whole cast is excellent.  The choruses too.If you don't know the opera, be sure to read up on it before watching.  It's not like BORIS GODUNOV, which explains itself as it goes along and in any event has a conventional plot.  The plot of KHOVANSHCHINA is very bewildering and choppy, a sequence of marginally-connected episodes, none of which make sense except in the historical context.  Fortunately, the context is easy enough to understand.  Tsar Peter is modernizing and two powerful forces are opposing his reforms: the "Streltsy", who are decomissioned elite career-soldiers (the word literally means the same as "musketeers") past their prime and on indefinite furlough; and, the Old Believers, Orthodox Christians who have split from the government-sponsored Church because She went along with Tsar Peter's reforms.  Fortunately for Tsar Peter, these two groups despise one other, the Streltsy being drunken roustabouts and the Old Believers being pious ascetics.  The three basses represent the three sides in this civil conflict: Prince Ivan Khovansky leads the Streltsy, and thinks he represents "true" Russia by noble birth and military prowess; Dosefei leads the Old Believers and thinks he represents "true" Russia's religious core; and Shaklovity supports Tsar Peter and thinks he represents "true" Russia which must modernize in order to remain part of the true world.  All the other characters are secondary.

reviewText: Abbado is a strong Mussorgsky-champion.He cares not for the Russian tradition, perhaps rightly so, because the tradition actually concerns Rimsky-Korsakov's version, while he uses Shostakovich's.Instead, he offers his own original ideas, treating the score as seriously as he would have treated a Wager or Mozart opera, with all the intellect and sophistication needed.For comparison, listen to Opera D'oro's release of La Scala's Khovanshchina led by the Russian Leskovich.Ghiaurov plays in both recordings the part of Ivan Khovansky.Here he is past his prime, but uses his vast experience to put on a credible performance.Paata Burchuladze is Dosifey. He has a subtle bass voice. He takes the opportunity to reach the low D in his great monolog.Still, he's a bit young for being a convincing Dosifey.Maybe he should have taken Khovansky and let Ghiaurov be Dosifey...Atlantov is strikingly great singing Andrey's ungratefully difficult tessitura.Kotcherga is in top shape (Strong voice, very strong). You get the notion why Abbado let him sing Boris in his later recording of Boris Godunov.Semtschuk succeeds most of the time to push her chest tones, except for some slips, but she is obviously more comfortable in the higher register.The orchestra and choir are musically flourished, although their pronouncing of the Russian words is obscure.P.S It is also nice to have Zednick as the Scribbler!
